title: Letter: An industrial ‘ecosystem' is nothing of the sort
text:
Alexandra Heal's excellent article about wireless earbuds sounded a loud and clear warning about the growing menace of e-waste (“Après moi . . .”, Magazine, FT Weekend, January 22), in particular, of the nano variety. I shall all the more fiercely cherish my large, over-ear, wired headphones, already in their 15th year. I was dismayed, though, to see her succumb to the fashionable use of the word “ecosystem” as a synonym for “system”, when she writes of Apple's “ever-growing ecosystem of gadgets”.

It is not her intention to suggest that Apple's version of these gadgets is somehow “greener” and environmentally better than others — quite the contrary, of course — but that is the connotation of “ecosystem”.

Such collocations as “industrial ecosystem” and “production ecosystem” are not just oxymorons: they are disingenuous, even deceitful, given the harm caused by industry and production to the natural environment, the real “ecosystem”.

Soon, if this trend is not checked, the word will be so degraded that, to refer to the actual ecosystem, we will have to use the tautology “environmental ecosystem”.

Christopher English
Cushendall, County Antrim, UK
